t: Nahum 1
The*p pronouncement concerning Nineveh. The book of the vision of Nahum the Elkoshite.
God’s Vengeance
The*pn Lord*s is a jealous and avenging God; the*ln Lord*s takes vengeance and*ln is fierce in wrath. The*ln Lord*s takes vengeance against his foes; he*ln is furious with his enemies.
The*ln Lord*s is slow to anger but great in power; the*ln Lord*s will never leave the guilty unpunished. His*ln path is in the whirlwind and storm, and*ln clouds are the dust beneath his feet.
He*ln rebukes the sea and dries it up, and*ln he makes all the rivers run dry. Bashan*ln and Carmel wither; even*ln the flower of Lebanon withers.
The*ln mountains quake before him, and*ln the hills melt; the*ln earth trembles at his presence — the*ln world and all who live in it.
Who*ln can withstand his indignation? Who*ln can endure his burning anger? His*ln wrath is poured out like fire; even*ln rocks are shattered before him.
Destruction of Nineveh
The*pn Lord*s is good, a*ln stronghold in a day of distress; he*ln cares for those who take refuge in him.
But*ln he will completely destroy Nineveh with*ln an overwhelming flood, and*ln he will chase his enemies into darkness.
Whatever*pn you plot against the Lord,*s he*ln will bring it to complete destruction; oppression*ln will not rise up a second time.
For*ln they will be consumed like*ln entangled thorns, like*ln the drink of a drunkard and*ln like straw that is fully dry.
One*ln has gone out from you, who*ln plots evil against the Lord,*s and*ln is a wicked counselor.
Promise of Judah’s Deliverance
This*p is what the Lord*s says: Though*pn they are strong and numerous, they*ln will still be mowed down, and*ln he will pass away. Though*ln I have punished you, I*ln will punish you no longer.
For*ln I will now break off his yoke from you and*ln tear off your shackles.
The Assyrian King’s Demise

The*p Lord*s has issued an order concerning you: There*pn will be no offspring to*ln carry on your name. I*ln will eliminate the carved idol and cast image from*ln the house of your gods; I*ln will prepare your grave, for*ln you are contemptible.

Look*pn to the mountains — the*ln feet of the herald, who*ln proclaims peace. Celebrate*ln your festivals, Judah; fulfill*ln your vows. For*ln the wicked one will never again march*ln through you; he*ln will be entirely wiped out.
Nahum 2
Attack against Nineveh
One*pn who scatters is coming up against you. Man*ln the fortifications! Watch*ln the road! Brace*ln yourself! Summon*ln all your strength!
For*pn the Lord*s will restore the majesty of Jacob, yes,*ln the majesty of Israel, though*ln ravagers have ravaged them and*ln ruined their vine branches.

The*pn shields of his warriors are dyed red; the*ln valiant men are dressed in scarlet. The*ln fittings of the chariot flash like fire on*ln the day of its battle preparations, and*ln the spears are brandished.
The*ln chariots dash madly through the streets; they*ln rush around in the plazas. They*ln look like torches; they*ln dart back and forth like lightning.
He*ln gives orders to his officers; they*ln stumble as they advance. They*ln race to its wall; the*ln protective shield is set in place.
The*ln river gates are opened, and*ln the palace erodes away.
Beauty*pn is stripped; she*ln is carried away; her*ln ladies-in-waiting moan like*ln the sound of doves and*ln beat their breasts.
Nineveh*ln has been like a pool of water from*ln her first days, but*ln they are fleeing. “Stop!*ln Stop!” they cry, but*ln no one turns back.
“Plunder*ln the silver! Plunder the gold!” There*ln is no end to the treasure, an*ln abundance of every precious thing.
Desolation,*ln decimation, devastation! Hearts*ln melt, knees*ln tremble, insides*ln churn, every*ln face grows pale!
Where*pn is the lions’ lair, or*ln the feeding ground of the young lions, where*ln the lion and lioness prowled, and*ln the lion’s cub, with*ln nothing to frighten them away?
The*ln lion mauled whatever its cubs needed and*ln strangled prey for its lionesses. It*ln filled up its dens with the kill, and*ln its lairs with mauled prey.

Beware,*ln I am against you. This*lg is the declaration of the Lord*s of Armies. I*pn will make your chariots go up in smoke, and*ln the sword will devour your young lions. I*ln will cut off your prey from the earth, and*ln the sound of your messengers will*ln never be heard again.
Nahum 3
Nineveh’s Downfall
Woe*pn to the city of blood, totally*ln deceitful, full*ln of plunder, never*ln without prey.
The*ln crack of the whip and*ln rumble of the wheel, galloping*ln horse and*ln jolting chariot!
Charging*ln horseman, flashing*ln sword, shining*ln spear; heaps*ln of slain, mounds*ln of corpses, dead*ln bodies without end— they*ln stumble over their dead.
Because*ln of the continual prostitution of the prostitute, the*ln attractive mistress of sorcery, who*ln treats nations and clans like merchandise by*ln her prostitution and sorcery,
I*ln am against you. This*lg is the declaration of the Lord*s of Armies. I*pn will lift your skirts over your face and*ln display your nakedness to nations, your*ln shame to kingdoms.
I*ln will throw filth on you and*ln treat you with contempt; I*ln will make a spectacle of you.
Then*ln all who see you will recoil from you, saying, “Nineveh*ln is devastated; who*ln will show sympathy to her?” Where*ln can I find anyone to comfort you?
Are*pn you better than Thebes that*ln sat along the Nile with*ln water surrounding her, whose*ln rampart was the sea, the*ln river her wall?
Cush*ln and Egypt were her endless source of strength; Put*ln and Libya were among her allies.

Yet*ln she became an exile; she*ln went into captivity. Her*ln children were also dashed to pieces at*ln the head of every street. They*ln cast lots for her dignitaries, and*ln all her nobles were bound in chains.
You*ln also will become drunk; you*ln will hide. You*ln also will seek refuge from the enemy.
All*pn your fortresses are fig trees with*ln figs that ripened first; when*ln shaken, they fall — right*ln into the mouth of the eater!
Look,*pn your troops are like women among you; your*ln land’s city gates are*ln wide open to your enemies. Fire*ln will devour the bars of your gates.
Draw*pn water for the siege; strengthen*ln your fortresses. Step*ln into the clay and tread the mortar; take*ln hold of the brick-mold!
The*ln fire will devour you there; the*ln sword will cut you down. It*ln will devour you like the young locust. Multiply*ln yourselves like the young locust; multiply*ln like the swarming locust!
You*ln have made your merchants more*ln numerous than the stars of the sky. The*ln young locust strips the land and*ln flies away.

Your*ln court officials are like the swarming locust, and*ln your scribes like clouds of locusts, which*ln settle on the walls on a cold day; when*ln the sun rises, they take off, and*ln no one knows where they are.
King*pn of Assyria, your shepherds slumber; your*ln officers sleep. Your*ln people are scattered across the mountains with*ln no one to gather them together.
There*ln is no remedy for your injury; your*ln wound is severe. All*ln who hear the news about you will*ln clap their hands because of you, for*ln who has not experienced your*ln constant cruelty?
